repository_info.description: Framework for orchestrating role-playing, autonomous AI agents. By fostering collaborative intelligence, CrewAI empowers agents to work together seamlessly, tackling complex tasks.

issues.title: [BUG] CrewAI does not work when in Docker when setting (allow_code_execution=True) in an Agent
issues.body:
### Description

Currently when you set `allow_code_execution=True,` and you are running in Docker you get an error. 

`   raise RuntimeError(
RuntimeError: Docker is not installed. Please install Docker to use code execution with agent: Knowledge Pattern Synthesizera`

CrewAI runs well for everything else in docker and the only workaround is to set `run_codes = CodeInterpreterTool(unsafe_mode=True)` this is not ideal.

Can we resolve the issue to work in Docker or state in the Documentation that CrewAI does work work with Docker to run code. 

### Steps to Reproduce

Create a standard agent and turn on the flag in the agent

            allow_code_execution=True,

Following https://docs.crewai.com/learn/coding-agents


### Expected behavior

Should run the code without errors 

### Screenshots/Code snippets

 def knowledge_synthesizer(self) -> Agent:
        return Agent(
            config=self.agents_config['knowledge_synthesizer'], 
            verbose=True,
            memory=True,
            allow_code_execution=True,
            max_retry_limit=3
        )

### Operating System

macOS Sonoma

### Python Version

3.12

### crewAI Version

0.130.0

### crewAI Tools Version

0.130.0

### Virtual Environment

Venv

### Evidence

root@3b97282c2dd0:/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai# crewai run
Running the Crew
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/src/create_crewai/main.py", line 26, in run

    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

    self._map_task_variables(
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/crewai/project/crew_base.py", line 232, in _map_task_variables
    self.tasks_config[task_name]["agent"] = agents[agent_name]()
                                            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/crewai/project/utils.py", line 11, in memoized_func
    cache[key] = func(*args, **kwargs)
                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/src/create_crewai/crew.py", line 55, in knowledge_synthesizer
    return Agent(
           ^^^^^^
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pydantic/main.py", line 253, in __init__
    validated_self = self.__pydantic_validator__.validate_python(data, self_instance=self)
                     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/crewai/agent.py", line 186, in post_init_setup
    self._validate_docker_installation()
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/.venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/crewai/agent.py", line 670, in _validate_docker_installation

RuntimeError: Docker is not installed. Please install Docker to use code execution with agent: Knowledge Pattern Synthesizer


During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/crewai/dev/code/create_crewai/.venv/bin/run_crew", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(run())

    raise Exception(f"An error occurred while running the crew: {e}")
Exception: An error occurred while running the crew: Docker is not installed. Please install Docker to use code execution with agent: Knowledge Pattern Synthesizer

An error occurred while running the crew: Command '['uv', 'run', 'run_crew']' returned non-zero exit status 1.

### Possible Solution

Enable Crewai Code to run in Docker

### Additional context

Is a blocker... as without the fix I will need to run from the file system

issues.title: [FEATURE] How the system and user prompts are generated?
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Documentation

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

NA

### Describe the solution you'd like

This is an example of system and user prompt from 1 run of Crew AI.
Could you provide an answer of provide documentation related to the prompt generation?

I didn't provide all the text below. My questions are 
How can we modify the default text in system and user prompt?
What is the argument to pass to get format in the system prompt?

System prompt
```
You are {Agent Role}. {Agent backstroy}.
Your personal goal is: {Agent goal}
To give my best complete final answer to the task respond using the exact following format:
{how to pass desired format?} 

Thought: I now can give a great answer
Final Answer: Your final answer must be the great and the most complete as possible, it must be outcome described.
I MUST use these formats, my job depends on it!
```

User prompt
```
{user provided Task descriptiopn}
This is the expected criteria for your final answer:  {Task expected_output}
you MUST return the actual complete content as the final answer, not a summary.
Ensure your final answer contains only the content in the following format:
{ dump of pydantic or json schema showing the name and its type}
Ensure the final output does not include any code block markers like ```json or ```python.

Begin! This is VERY important to you, use the tools available and give your best Final Answer, your job depends on it!

Thought:
```

The litellm completion call also stops at stop=['\nObservation:'].
How to modify this argument?

Passing verbose option True to Crew and Task didn't dump the above text. 
Could you add an option to dump all the text/messages that go into LLM?

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Willingness to Contribute

No, I'm just suggesting the idea

issues.title: [BUG] CrewAI is not working with Gemini and HuggingFace LLMs
issues.body:
### Description

Any LLM other than OpenAI raises an exception that the LLM calls can't be made or API request error or Bad request even after checking permissions and key validity.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use the LLM class in crewai
2. Use any model other than OpenAI (Gemini or HuggingFace providers)
3. Use keys from .env 
4. Make an LLM call 
5. It will rasie an exception that LLM call was None or any other error.

### Expected behavior

I was using the Huggingface token to connect to Meta Llama LLMs for a test. When using the Huggingface token, it redirects to a new address. 

### Screenshots/Code snippets

from crewai import Agent, Crew, Process, Task, LLM
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load environment variables from .env file
load_dotenv()

llm_hf = LLM(
    model="huggingface/meta-llama/Meta-Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct",  # You can change to any supported Hugging Face model
    temperature=0.7,
    api_key=os.getenv("HUGGINGFACE_API_KEY")
)

### Operating System

Windows 10

### Python Version

3.11

### crewAI Version

crewai version: 0.130.0

### crewAI Tools Version

crewai-tools: 0.47.1

### Virtual Environment

Venv

### Evidence

Traceback (most recent call last):
    response = base_llm_http_handler.completion(
               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    data = provider_config.transform_request(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    provider_mapping = _fetch_inference_provider_mapping(model_id)
                       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    raise HuggingFaceError(
.HuggingFaceError: Failed to fetch provider mapping: Redirect response '307 Temporary Redirect' for url 'https://huggingface.co/api/models/meta-llama/Meta-Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct?expand=inferenceProviderMapping'
Redirect location: '/api/models/meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct?expand=inferenceProviderMapping'
For more information check: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/307

### Possible Solution

Update the LLM class to either use providers for inference

### Additional context

None

issues.title: [BUG] Pydantic Schema Validation in CrewAI Events
issues.body:
### Description

When integrating CrewAI agents with Render, we encountered a Pydantic validation error in **LLMCallStartedEvent** due to an internal `TokenCalcHandler` object being passed instead of a plain `dict`. This is a regression caused by Pydantic v2â€™s `dict_type` checks.

uname -a
Linux srv-d1as1mer433s73adehbg-5db4c57b6-wqkdf 6.8.0-1023-aws #25~22.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Tue Jan 28 12:51:22 UTC 2025 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Environment

- **CrewAI version**: Latest PyPI release (Pydantic v2)
- **Python**: 3.13
- **Context**: Running on Render with telemetry enabled by default

Issue

**Error message**:

```
ValidationError: 1 validation error for LLMCallStartedEvent
tools.0
  Input should be a valid dictionary [type=dict_type, input_value=<TokenCalcHandler object>, input_type=TokenCalcHandler]
```

**Root cause**: CrewAIâ€™s `LLMCallStartedEvent` schema expects `tools: List[dict]`, but internally attaches a `TokenCalcHandler` instance in its `tools` list. Pydanticâ€™s `dict_type` check now rejects non-`dict` entries.


Linux srv-d1as1mer433s73adehbg-5db4c57b6-wqkdf 6.8.0-1023-aws #25~22.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Tue Jan 28 12:51:22 UTC 2025 x86_64 GNU/Linux


### Steps to Reproduce

Minimal Reproduction

python
from crewai.llm import LLM
from crewai.utilities.events.llm_events import LLMCallStartedEvent

# Simulate internal injection
event = LLMCallStartedEvent(
    messages=[...],
    tools=[{"name": "tool1"}, TokenCalcHandler(...)],
    token_handler=TokenCalcHandler(...)
)
# Raises ValidationError on initialization


### Expected behavior

Please update the CrewAI codebase to handle non-`dict` tool objects gracefully in `LLMCallStartedEvent`, and consider disabling telemetry or sanitizing events by default. This will prevent users from needing invasive monkey-patches and ensure compatibility with Pydantic v2.

### Screenshots/Code snippets

# Simulate internal injection
event = LLMCallStartedEvent(
    messages=[...],
    tools=[{"name": "tool1"}, TokenCalcHandler(...)],
    token_handler=TokenCalcHandler(...)
)
# Raises ValidationError on initialization

### Operating System

Other (specify in additional context)

### Python Version

3.12

### crewAI Version

 crewai: 0.130.0

### crewAI Tools Version

pydantic: 2.11.7

### Virtual Environment

Venv

### Evidence

ValidationError: 1 validation error for LLMCallStartedEvent
tools.0
  Input should be a valid dictionary [type=dict_type, input_value=<TokenCalcHandler object>, input_type=TokenCalcHandler]

### Possible Solution

1. **Schema change** in CrewAI: make `tools: List[Union[dict, Any]]` or filter out unknown types before validation.
2. **Optional field**: mark `token_handler` in the `LLMCallStartedEvent` model as `Optional[Any]` and exclude it from schema validation.
3. **Utility filter**: add `.dict(exclude_unset=True, filter_func=isinstance(dict))` internally.

### Additional context

## Workaround (for users)

```python
import os
os.environ["CREWAI_DISABLE_TELEMETRY"] = "true"

# Monkey-patch event init to filter tools
from crewai.utilities.events.llm_events import LLMCallStartedEvent
_orig_init = LLMCallStartedEvent.__init__
def _safe_init(self, *args, tools=None, **kwargs):
    if isinstance(tools, list):
        tools = [t for t in tools if isinstance(t, dict)]
    kwargs.pop("token_handler", None)
    return _orig_init(self, *args, tools=tools, **kwargs)
LLMCallStartedEvent.__init__ = _safe_init
```

patches must placed above all calls, and possibly some imports
issues.author: jfbraman

issues.title: [FEATURE] Documentation for Custom pgvector Knowledge Storage is missing
issues.body:
**Feature Area:** Documentation

**Is your feature request related to an existing bug? Please link it here.**
NA

**Describe the solution you'd like**
There should be clear and comprehensive documentation for using a custom pgvector as the knowledge storage in CrewAI. This should include setup instructions, configuration details, example use cases, and troubleshooting tips for users who want to use or integrate a custom pgvector database as their knowledge storage backend.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I tried searching the existing documentation and repository wiki, but could not find detailed information about configuring or using a custom pgvector as the knowledge storage.

**Additional context**
Proper documentation will help users and contributors effectively use, configure, and extend CrewAI with a custom pgvector knowledge storage option.

**Willingness to Contribute:**
I can test the feature once it's implemented.

issues.body:
### Description

I have some crews that follow the same model as the one I'm putting below, and in some executions it ends up finishing the response prematurely, like in the middle of some agent's thought process. I'll leave an example of a response I received.

MODEL:
`OPENAI_MODEL_NAME=gpt-4o`

My Crew
```

    tasks_config = 'config/tasks.yaml'

        return build_senior_product(tools=[
            directory_tools(),
            read_output_file(FileEnum.FILE_NAME),
        ])

            directory_tools(),

        ])

        return build_canvas_mvp_task()

        """Cria a crew de criaÃ§Ã£o do Canvas MVP"""

issues.title: [BUG] Human In The Loop input cannot enter
issues.body:
### Description

How can I perform the operations in the document at https://docs.crewai.com/learn/human-in-the-loop? When I run CrewAI with CrewRun, an endpoint is not started. For this reason, I do not have a KICKOFF endpoint. When I log in to the CLI, the data I enter does not appear in the terminal.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2a0b65d4-e00e-40f7-8306-f48715435a88)

### Steps to Reproduce

Streaming starts with CrewAI Run but I can't enter input.

### Expected behavior

Progress of the process or logging into the terminal with the KIOCKOFF endpoint


### Screenshots/Code snippets

```
    @task
    def research_task(self) -> Task:
        return Task(
            config=self.tasks_config['research_task'], 
            output_json=CaseClassificationResponse,
            human_input=True
        )

```

Ubuntu 20.04

### Python Version

3.10

-

-

### Virtual Environment

Venv

-

-

issues.title: [BUG] Type annotation for `context` in `Task` is `Optional[List["Task"]]`, but default is `NOT_SPECIFIED`
issues.body:
### Description

In [`src/crewai/task.py`](https://github.com/crewAIInc/crewAI/blob/db1e9e9b9a689bf85f12e2f848f24f2d31518530/src/crewai/task.py#L98-L101), the `context` field is annotated as `Optional[List["Task"]]`, but the default value is set to `NOT_SPECIFIED`, which is neither `None` nor a `List["Task"]`. This could cause confusion for type checkers and consumers of the API.

```python
context: Optional[List["Task"]] = Field(
    description="Other tasks that will have their output used as context for this task.",
    default=NOT_SPECIFIED,
)
```

### Steps to Reproduce

See description

### Expected behavior

The type annotation should include `NOT_SPECIFIED` as a valid value, or the default should be changed to `None` if only `None` or `List["Task"]` are allowed

### Screenshots/Code snippets

See description

### Operating System

Ubuntu 20.04

issues.title: Ollama LLM not working with crewai agents ("LLM Failed" error)
issues.body:
### Description

## Summary
Ollama works directly in Python, but fails with "LLM Failed" when used as an agent LLM in crewai. Ollama server logs show no requests from crewai.

## Environment
- Python: 3.10
- crewai: <your version>
- langchain: <your version>
- langchain-ollama: <your version>
- ollama: <your version>

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Start Ollama server (`ollama serve`)
2. Run this minimal crewai script:

```python
from crewai import Agent, Task, Crew, Process
from langchain_ollama import OllamaLLM

llm = OllamaLLM(model="deepseek-r1:latest", base_url="http://127.0.0.1:11434")

agent = Agent(
    role="Test Agent",
    goal="Say hello",
    backstory="You are a helpful assistant.",
    llm=llm
)

task = Task(
    description="Say hello",
    expected_output="A friendly greeting from the assistant.",
    agent=agent
)

crew = Crew(
    agents=[agent],
    tasks=[task],
    process=Process.sequential,
    verbose=True
)

crew.kickoff()

do python test.py to replicate same behavior using Ollama model

issues.title: [FEATURE] Improved pydantic_output task if fields descriptions are used
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Core functionality

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

Currently if you use `pydantic_output` for task it will include instructions to LLM like this:

Schema: 

```
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field

class ResponseLimit(BaseModel):
    min_words: int
    max_words: int
    reason: str
```

Instructions:

```
Ensure your final answer contains only the content in the following format: {
  "min_words": int,
  "max_words": int,
  "reason": str
}
```

However if i try to add some details for pydantic_output similar what we do for tools with `args_schema` like this:

Schema with descriptions:

```
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field

class ResponseLimit(BaseModel):
    min_words: int = Field(..., description="Minimum number of words")
    max_words: int = Field(..., description="Maximum number of words")
    reason: str = Field(..., description="Reason this decision is made.")

```

It will still have the same instructions as listed above. 


### Describe the solution you'd like

I would love for tool to detect if `Fields` are assigned and include it as JSON schema, something like that:

```
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field

class ResponseLimit(BaseModel):
    min_words: int = Field(..., description="Minimum number of words")
    max_words: int = Field(..., description="Maximum number of words")
    reason: str = Field(..., description="Reason this decision is made")

```

It will include instructions like this: 

```
Ensure your final answer follows this JSON schema: {
  "min_words": {'description': 'Minimum number of words', 'type': 'int'},
  "max_words": {'description': 'Maximum number of words', 'type': 'int'},
  "reason": {'description': 'Reason this decision is made', 'type': 'str'},
}
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Of cause you can always manually describe on `expected_output` each field, but it would be nice if you don't have to do that and it is taken from `pydantic ouput` as well.

### Additional context

_No response_

### Willingness to Contribute

Yes, I'd be happy to submit a pull request

issues.title: [FEATURE] Agent tools instructions
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Agent capabilities

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

NA

### Describe the solution you'd like

Yesterday, during a live demo by @vladeziegler on [AI Agent Weekâ€”Portugal](https://lu.ma/lisbonagentweek?tk=GqGTK6), I realized that he had the same problem as I had multiple times. 

The idea is that we have an Agent with a `role`, `goal`, and `backstory`. The agent also has `tools` that are semantically correct to assign to it.

The problem is that you often want to instruct agents on how to use some tools. But semantically, it is not clear where to do that. Usually your best options are task description itself of backstory. 

The task option does not sound very good since tasks are detached from agents. The backstory also looks semantically incorrect since it must be some story about an agent and not a specific tool.

So I propose to create an additional level of abstractions to make things look better:

```python
from crew import ToolWithInstruction
from crewai_tools import ScrapeWebsiteTool

tool_with_instruction = ToolWithInstruction(
  ScrapeWebsiteTool(),
  """
  ALWAYS use this tool when making a joke.
  NEVER use this tool when making joke about someones mom.
  """
)

agent = Agent(
           role="Comedian",
           goal="Create hilarious and engaging jokes",
           backstory="""
                 You are a professional stand-up comedian with years of experience in crafting jokes.
                  You have a great sense of humor and can create jokes about any topic while keeping them appropriate and entertaining.
           """,
            tools=[tool_with_instruction],
        )
```

So now we will somehow include these instructions when prompting LLM with tool and from framework it looks consistent. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered

They way i am doing it right now is:

```python
from crewai_tools import ScrapeWebsiteTool

agent = Agent(
           role="Comedian",
           goal="Create hilarious and engaging jokes",
           backstory="""
                 You are a professional stand-up comedian with years of experience in crafting jokes.
                 You have a great sense of humor and can create jokes about any topic while keeping them appropriate and entertaining.
                 ALWAYS use ScrapeWebsiteTool tool when making a joke.
                 NEVER use ScrapeWebsiteTool when making joke about someones mom.
           """,
            tools=[ScrapeWebsiteTool()],
        )
```

It does a job, but it always feels a bit wrong to put such things in the backstory. With multiple tools assigned it also looks messy.

### Additional context

_No response_

### Willingness to Contribute

Yes, I'd be happy to submit a pull request

issues.title: [BUG] PDFSearchTool gives OPENAI API error after setting custom configuration
issues.body:
### Description

Environment Details
Anaconda = 3.12.9
Crewai = 0.120.1
Crewai Tools = 0.45.0
OS = Windows 10
While executing a task within the AWS Marketplace support query analyst crew, the process fails due to an authentication error with the OpenAI API. The error message indicates that the api_key client option is missing and must be set either by passing the api_key to the client or by setting the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable.

Notably, I have a custom configuration in place that is designed to skip OpenAI API calls (e.g., for local testing or using a mock LLM), but despite this configuration, the system still attempts to call the OpenAI API and fails due to missing authentication.

This results in the task failing and the overall crew execution stopping prematurely.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set up the crew environment.
2. Configure the system with a custom setting intended to skip OpenAI API calls (e.g., using a mock LLM or bypass).
3. Run the crew to process a task related to analyzing and classifying customer queries for AWS Marketplace.
4. Observe that the task execution attempts to call the OpenAI API despite the custom configuration to skip it.
5. The process fails with an authentication error indicating the missing api_key or environment variable.
6. The entire crew execution terminates with the error:
`litellm.AuthenticationError: AuthenticationError: OpenAIException - The api_key client option must be set either by passing api_key to the client or by setting the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable`

### Expected behavior

When the custom configuration to skip OpenAI API calls is enabled, the system should not attempt to call the OpenAI API.

The crew should either:
Use the mock or local LLM as configured, bypassing authentication requirements,
Or gracefully handle the scenario without throwing an authentication error.

The task should execute successfully or return appropriate responses without failing due to missing API keys.

Overall crew execution should complete without errors related to OpenAI API authentication when skipping is configured.

### Screenshots/Code snippets

`from crewai_tools import PDFSearchTool

tool = PDFSearchTool(
    pdf=pdf_path,
    config=dict(
        llm=dict(
            provider="ollama",  # If you're using Ollama as LLM provider
            config=dict(
                base_url="http://localhost:10000",  # MSTY service endpoint
                model="llama3.2:latest",  # Example LLM model, update if needed
            ),
        ),
        embedder=dict(
            provider="huggingface",  # Embedding using MSTY/Ollama
            config=dict(
                model="sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2",  # Embedding model
            ),
        ),
    )
)
`

### Operating System

Windows 10

### Python Version

3.12

### crewAI Version

0.120.1

### crewAI Tools Version

0.45.0

### Virtual Environment

Venv

### Evidence

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/30373fe3-fc2f-4a0b-a9a7-ec6283d210b4)

### Possible Solution

Ensure that the custom configuration to skip OpenAI API calls is properly integrated and respected throughout the entire codebase, especially in the task execution and LLM invocation layers.

Add conditional checks before any OpenAI client instantiation or call to verify if the skip flag/configuration is active, and if so, bypass any OpenAI-related code paths.

Implement a fallback or mock LLM client that can be used when skipping OpenAI, preventing the system from trying to authenticate with a missing API key.

Improve error handling to catch missing API key errors early and provide clearer messaging or fallback behavior.

Consider setting default environment variables or configuration values to avoid accidental missing keys during development or testing.

### Additional context

N/A

issues.title: [FEATURE] Support Fallback LLMs for Agent Execution
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Agent capabilities

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

No

### Describe the solution you'd like

Hi CrewAI team ðŸ‘‹

Thanks for building such an elegant and modular agent framework â€” itâ€™s been a joy to work with CrewAI!

### ðŸ’¡ Feature Request

I'd like to request **support for fallback LLMs at the Agent level**, to improve robustness and flexibility in production environments.

### ðŸš© Motivation

Currently, each agent is tied to a single `llm` instance. However, in real-world scenarios, LLMs may:

* Fail due to latency or API issues
* Produce poor or incomplete responses
* Exceed rate limits

Having a fallback mechanism â€” where another LLM is tried if the first one fails â€” would significantly increase the reliability of multi-agent tasks.

### âœ… Example API

```python
Agent(
    role="primary_researcher",
    goal="Extract insights from the document",
    llm=gpt4,
    fallback=[qwen3, mistral7b]
)
```

### ðŸ”§ Expected Behavior

* If `gpt4` fails (timeout, error, or poor output), CrewAI should automatically try `qwen3`, then `mistral7b` as a last resort.
* Ideally, the fallback can be configured to trigger on specific error types or confidence thresholds.

### ðŸ§  Why This Matters

* Enables graceful degradation during outages
* Reduces failure points in production deployments
* Allows for cost-performance tradeoffs (e.g., fall back from expensive LLMs to cheaper ones)

Let me know if this fits with the project vision â€” Iâ€™d be happy to contribute or collaborate on a PR if helpful!

Thanks again for your incredible work ðŸ™

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Willingness to Contribute

I can test the feature once it's implemented
issues.author: redvelvets

comments.author: redvelvets
comments.body: Support triggering based on specific failure types (e.g., exceptions, timeouts, or low-quality responses), or generic errors.

issues.title: [BUG] use of mcp server in crewai causes recursion limit error
issues.body:
### Description

I tried to use mcp server with crewai. I have used the same exact example from the documentation and i have received this error:

### **Server code:**
================

`"""A simple Math MCP server that implements the Model Context Protocol.

This server provides mathematical operations as tools that can be discovered and used by MCP clients.
"""

from mcp.server.fastmcp import FastMCP
mcp = FastMCP("Math")

@mcp.tool()
def add(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """Add two numbers (ints or floats)"""
    return a + b

@mcp.tool()
def subtract(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """Subtract b from a (ints or floats)"""
    return a - b

@mcp.tool()
def multiply(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """Multiply two numbers (ints or floats)"""
    return a * b

@mcp.tool()
def divide(numerator: float, denominator: float) -> float:
    """Divide numerator by denominator (floats ok)"""
    if denominator == 0:
        raise ValueError("Cannot divide by zero")
    return numerator / denominator

@mcp.tool()
def power(base: float, exponent: float) -> float:
    """Raise base to the power of exponent (floats ok)"""
    return base ** exponent

@mcp.tool()
def sqrt(number: float) -> float:
    """Calculate the square root of a number"""
    if number < 0:
        raise ValueError("Cannot calculate square root of a negative number")
    return number ** 0.5

if __name__ == "__main__":
    mcp.run(transport="stdio")`

### **Client code:**
================
`from crewai import Agent, Task, Crew
from crewai_tools import MCPServerAdapter
from mcp import StdioServerParameters
import os

stdio_params=StdioServerParameters(command="python3", 
                                    args=["math_server_stdio.py"],
                                    env={"UV_PYTHON": "3.13", **os.environ},
                                )

with MCPServerAdapter(stdio_params) as tools:
    print(f"Available tools from Stdio MCP server: {[tool.name for tool in tools]}")

    agent = Agent(role="Mathematician",
                goal="Perform mathematical operations.",
                backstory="An experienced mathematician that can perform mathematical operations via MCP tools.",
                tools=tools,
                verbose=True,
            )

    task = Task(description="Solve the math {problem} given to you by the user.",
                expected_output="The correct answer to the math problem using the available tools.",
                agent=agent,
            )

    crew = Crew(agents=[agent],
                tasks=[task],
                verbose=True,
            )

    result = crew.kickoff(inputs = {'problem': "calculate the square root of 17?"})
    print(result)`



### Steps to Reproduce

Follow the documentation and the code exactly as it is and you will get the error

### Expected behavior

Agent should understand what tool it is and use the tool based on the context and return the results.

### Screenshots/Code snippets

Here is the error i have got:

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RecursionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
File ~/my_projects/8.mcp/.venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/IPython/core/formatters.py:282, in catch_format_error(method, self, *args, **kwargs)
    281 try:

issues.title: [FEATURE] crewAI - lite
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Core functionality

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

The crewAI is awesome solution. Nevertheless the current version of the crewAI is **extremely bloated** with dependencies. This makes the installation heavy and extremely vulnerable to CVE of the dependencies.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Please consider to have something like very bare bone crewAI lib and then additional functionalities via "extras package".

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Replace crewAI with own implementation that will contain only needed functionality.

### Additional context

_No response_

### Willingness to Contribute

Yes, I'd be happy to submit a pull request

issues.title: [BUG] CrewAi Custom LLM is not calling get_context_window_size function
issues.body:
### Description

I've created a Custom LLM class based on the documentation, basic functionality works but get_context_window_size function was never called. So CrewAi just passed everything and caused token/context exceeded error. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create CustomLLM per the documentation here: https://docs.crewai.com/learn/custom-llm
2. try to create an agent and task that exceed the maximum context supported by your model. By default, crewai should know that it exceeded the context size and need to summarize it since respect_context_window is True by default. But you ends up getting an error such as 400 bad request because your prompt is too big

CrewAI is supposed to call the get_context_window_size function to determine the context window size and then summarize the content if the context is too large.

issues.title: [BUG] Crew cannot be run because of incompatible Pydantic version
issues.body:
### Description

Currently, crew ai `pyproject.toml` has `pydantic>=2.4.2` version constraint. However, there is an incompatibility issue with Pydantic versions less than 2.8.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new crew project: `crewai create crew example-app`
2. Add Pydantic version 2.7: `uv add pydantic==2.7.4`
3. Install dependencies: `crewai install`
4. Run the app: `crewai run`
5. There is an exception about Pydantic `ValidationInfo`

### Expected behavior

The crew should be successfully run without any exceptions.

### Screenshots/Code snippets

`pyproject.toml` file

```toml
[project]
name = "latest_ai_development"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "latest-ai-development using crewAI"
authors = [{ name = "Your Name", email = "you@example.com" }]
requires-python = ">=3.10,<3.13"
dependencies = [

issues.title: [BUG] NoneType Error when failing to convert text into Pydantic Model
issues.body:
### Description

### Description:
When CrewAI is continuously failing to convert an output to a pydantic model, this error occurs. It is not intended within the code and doesn't give much info on what happened.

### Error Messages:
`Failed to add to long term memory: Failed to convert text into a Pydantic model due to error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'function_calling_llm'`
`Error in method run_custom_crew: Failed to convert text into a Pydantic model due to error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 
'function_calling_llm'`



### Steps to Reproduce

This happens when converting text to a pydantic model continuously fails. 

The quickest way to reproduce this is to use a very **small llm**, and a **complex pydantic model** for `output_pydantic` within a crew. This way the conversion will likely continuously fail.

The model I was using to come across this was llama 3.2 3b.

### Expected behavior

There should be a clean resolution given to the user along the lines of `Failure to convert output to Pydantic Model` here instead of the current error. Clear resolution for the long term memory error would be great as I don't know the trace of this from the output given.

### Screenshots/Code snippets

### Source of error:
Line 193 fails here when agent is None. 
https://github.com/crewAIInc/crewAI/blob/d92382b6cf422e62d1b771d50dd44fbf5c739f1f/src/crewai/utilities/converter.py#L186-L193

This happens on line 40 when Converter(...).to_pydantic() is called and a ValidationError occurs.
https://github.com/crewAIInc/crewAI/blob/d92382b6cf422e62d1b771d50dd44fbf5c739f1f/src/crewai/utilities/converter.py#L23-L40


### Operating System

Ubuntu 20.04

### Python Version

3.11

### crewAI Version

0.130.0

### crewAI Tools Version

0.47.1

### Virtual Environment

Conda

### Evidence

### Common traces:

<details>
  <summary>
    Converting a task output to pydantic model
  </summary>

```

    return self._execute_tasks(self.tasks)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/crew.py", line 871, in _execute_tasks
    task_output = task.execute_sync(
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/task.py", line 351, in execute_sync
    return self._execute_core(agent, context, tools)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/task.py", line 499, in _execute_core
    raise e  # Re-raise the exception after emitting the event
    ^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/task.py", line 421, in _execute_core
    pydantic_output, json_output = self._export_output(result)
                                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/task.py", line 695, in _export_output
    model_output = convert_to_model(
                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 133, in convert_to_model
    return handle_partial_json(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 183, in handle_partial_json
    return convert_with_instructions(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 206, in convert_with_instructions
    converter.to_pydantic() if not is_json_output else converter.to_json()
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 68, in to_pydantic
    return self.to_pydantic(current_attempt + 1)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 68, in to_pydantic
    return self.to_pydantic(current_attempt + 1)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 69, in to_pydantic
    raise ConverterError(
crewai.utilities.converter.ConverterError: Failed to convert text into a Pydantic model due to error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'function_calling_llm'
[Flow._execute_single_listener] Error in method get_targets: Failed to convert text into a Pydantic model due to error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 
'function_calling_llm'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 38, in 
to_pydantic
    result = self.model.model_validate_json(response)
             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/pydantic/main.py", line 744, in model_validate_json
    return cls.__pydantic_validator__.validate_json(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
pydantic_core._pydantic_core.ValidationError: 1 validation error for TargetModel
  Invalid JSON: EOF while parsing an object at line 3 column 562 [type=json_invalid, input_value='{\n  "targets": ["l...check first"', input_type=str]
    For further information visit https://errors.pydantic.dev/2.11/v/json_invalid

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 42, in 
to_pydantic
    result = handle_partial_json(response, self.model, False, None)
             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 183, in 
handle_partial_json
    return convert_with_instructions(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "<conda_env_path>/lib/python3.11/site-packages/crewai/utilities/converter.py", line 195, in 
convert_with_instructions
    llm = agent.function_calling_llm or agent.llm
          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```
</details>


<details>
  <summary>
    Evaluation within long term memory 
  </summary>
This doesn't give a traceback, but here is my manual inspection starting at CrewAgentExecutor.invoke: 

_create_long_term_memory -> TaskEvaluator.evaluate -> Convert.to_pydantic -> handle_partial_json -> convert_with_instructions

Error is `Failed to add to long term memory: Failed to convert text into a Pydantic model due to error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'function_calling_llm'`

</details>

### Possible Solution

I'm not too sure how the intended flow should be in this continuous error case as `to_pydantic` and `handle_partial_json` are used in a couple different contexts. Note how in the first trace `handle_partial_json` gets revisited, so a loop needs to be avoided.

A quick fix would be checking whether Agent is None at this step and handling it accordingly.
https://github.com/crewAIInc/crewAI/blob/d92382b6cf422e62d1b771d50dd44fbf5c739f1f/src/crewai/utilities/converter.py#L180-L183



### Additional context

N/A

issues.title: [FEATURE] Stop hijacking sys.stdout and sys.stderr
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Core functionality

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

NA

### Describe the solution you'd like

Maybe I'm lacking context as an end user, but I don't see a functional reason why anyone `import`ing `crewai.llm` should suddenly be unable to log anything with the word `"litellm"` without themselves having to re-override `sys.stderr`.

https://github.com/crewAIInc/crewAI/blob/970a63c13c7ac94b5e016e529cf80693f9b53b05/src/crewai/llm.py#L119-L125

Philosophically, globally overriding `sys` attributes for every CrewAI user's Python application seems like a massive overstep, especially when it comes to filtering out terms without a user's consent or control.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

If you really really really really wanted to, you could wrap this module's `litellm` calls with [`contextlib.redirect_stdout()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.redirect_stdout), although the Python maintainers mention

> Note that the global side effect on [sys.stdout](https://docs.python.org/3/library/sys.html#sys.stdout) means that this context manager is not suitable for use in library code and most threaded applications.

further suggesting that modifying `sys.stdout` and `sys.stderr` in general is not a fantastic approach.

Or if altering the behavior of others' code is still on the table, you can probably monkey patch `litellm`'s logging handlers.

### Additional context

_No response_

### Willingness to Contribute

No, I'm just suggesting the idea

issues.title: [FEATURE] Auto Improvement Agentic Pipeline
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Core functionality

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

No

### Describe the solution you'd like

## Overview

The Auto Improve Agent is an intelligent optimization system that automatically improves crew configurations including task descriptions, expected outputs, agent goals, agent backstories, and manager configurations. This feature provides granular control over improvements while maintaining complete audit trails and rollback capabilities.

### Core Design Principles

- **Separation of Concerns**: Data collection is separated from optimization
- **Granular Control**: Selective improvement of specific agents/tasks
- **Versioning**: UUID-based archiving with complete history
- **Flexibility**: Different LLMs and strategies per improvement run
- **Auditability**: Comprehensive reports and rollback capabilities

### Key Components

**1. Data Collection via Crew Parameter**

```python
crew = Crew(
    agents=[researcher, writer, editor],
    tasks=[research_task, writing_task, editing_task],
    manager_llm="gpt-4",
    retain_improvement_logs=True,  # Enable improvement data collection
    log_retention_days=30,  # Optional: auto-cleanup old logs
    verbose=True
)
```

When `retain_improvement_logs=True`:

- Each execution captures inputs, outputs, and execution traces
- Automatically prompts for feedback after each run
- Stores data in structured format for analysis

**2. Feedback Collection**

```python
result = crew.kickoff(inputs={"topic": "AI Safety"})
# Automatic prompt when retain_improvement_logs=True:
# > Rate output quality (1-5): 4
# > What worked well?: Comprehensive research, good structure
# > What needs improvement?: More specific examples needed
# > Tags (optional): [research, technical]
```

**3. Granular Improvement Method**

```python
improvement_result = crew.improve(
    # LLM Configuration
    llm="claude-3-opus",  # LLM for improvement analysis
    
    # Selective Targeting
    agents=["researcher", "writer"],  # Specific agents to improve
    tasks=["research_task"],  # Specific tasks to improve
    improve_manager=True,  # Also optimize manager configuration
    
    # Optimization Settings
    objective="quality",  # Primary goal: "cost", "latency", "quality"
    constraints={
        "max_tokens_increase": 0.2,  # Don't increase prompts by >20%
        "preserve_tools": True,  # Don't remove existing tools
        "maintain_style": True,  # Preserve writing style/tone
    },
    
    # Validation Settings
    test_size=0.2,  # Hold-out validation set
    confidence_threshold=0.95,  # Minimum confidence for changes
    min_feedback_samples=10,  # Minimum data required
    
    # Approval Settings
    require_human_approval=True,  # Review before applying
    dry_run=False,  # If True, only generate report
)
```

**4. Advanced Features**

### Improvement Pipelines

```python
# Chain multiple targeted improvements
result = crew.improve_pipeline([
    {"agents": ["researcher"], "objective": "cost", "llm": "gpt-4"},
    {"tasks": ["writing_task"], "objective": "quality", "llm": "claude-3"},
    {"improve_manager": True, "objective": "latency", "llm": "gpt-4-turbo"}
])
```

### Reusable Improvement Policies

```python
# Define templates for common improvement scenarios
quality_policy = ImprovementPolicy(
    name="high_quality_output",
    llm="claude-3-opus",
    objective="quality",
    min_feedback_samples=50,
    confidence_threshold=0.95,
    constraints={
        "max_tokens_increase": 0.3,
        "preserve_tools": True,
    },
    require_human_approval=True
)

# Apply policy
crew.improve(policy=quality_policy, agents=["writer", "editor"])
```

### A/B Testing Framework

```python
# Test improvements in production
crew.improve(
    agents=["support_agent"],
    objective="quality",
    ab_test={
        "enabled": True,
        "traffic_split": 0.1,  # 10% traffic to improved version
        "duration_hours": 24,
        "metrics": ["user_satisfaction", "resolution_time"]
    }
)
```

**5. File Structure and Versioning**

```
project/
â”œâ”€â”€ crew_improvement/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ datasets/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ feedback/
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 2024-06-16_feedback.jsonl
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ 2024-06-17_feedback.jsonl
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ execution_logs/
â”‚   â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ 2024-06-16_logs.jsonl
â”‚   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ 2024-06-17_logs.jsonl
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ archive/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ improvement_7f3e4a12-8e9f-4b5c-9d23-3e4f5a6b7c8d/
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ metadata.json
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ changes/
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ agents/
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ researcher_before.yaml
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ researcher_after.yaml
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ researcher_diff.yaml
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ tasks/
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ research_task_diff.yaml
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ manager/
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”‚       â””â”€â”€ manager_config_diff.yaml
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ improvement_report.md
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ performance_metrics.json
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ validation_results.json
â”‚   â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ rollback.py
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ improvement_9b5c8d23-4a5b-6c7d-8e9f-0a1b2c3d4e5f/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ active/  # Current configuration
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ agents.yaml
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ tasks.yaml
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ version.json
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ reports/
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ improvement_history.html  # Visual dashboard
```

**6. Comprehensive Improvement Report**

```markdown
# Improvement Report: 7f3e4a12-8e9f-4b5c-9d23-3e4f5a6b7c8d

**Date**: 2024-06-16 14:30:00 UTC
**Initiated By**: user@example.com
**Objective**: Quality Optimization
**LLM Used**: claude-3-opus
**Status**: Applied Successfully

## Executive Summary
Successfully improved crew quality score by 27% based on analysis of 
50 feedback samples. Changes focused on enhancing researcher capabilities
and clarifying task expectations.

## Changes Applied

### Agent: Researcher
**Backstory** (Enhanced)
- Added: "Specializes in peer-reviewed sources and academic databases"
- Added: "Expert in distinguishing reliable sources from misinformation"
- Token increase: +45 tokens (12%)

**Goal** (Refined)
- Before: "Find relevant information"
- After: "Find and validate high-quality, relevant information from 
  authoritative sources, providing confidence scores for each source"

### Task: Research Task
**Description** (Clarified)
- Added structured output requirements
- Included minimum source requirements (5 sources, 3 peer-reviewed)
- Added citation format specifications

**Expected Output** (Detailed)
- Added example of ideal output format
- Specified required sections and word counts
- Included quality criteria checklist

### Manager Configuration
- Adjusted delegation strategy for better task distribution
- Added quality checkpoints between agent handoffs

## Performance Metrics

| Metric | Before | After | Change | Statistical Significance |
|--------|--------|-------|---------|-------------------------|
| Quality Score | 3.2/5 | 4.1/5 | +28% | p < 0.001 |
| Avg Completion Time | 45s | 48s | +7% | p = 0.12 |
| Success Rate | 78% | 92% | +18% | p < 0.01 |
| Token Usage | 1,250 | 1,380 | +10% | - |
| Cost per Run | $0.045 | $0.049 | +9% | - |

## Validation Results
- Training Set: 40 examples
- Test Set: 10 examples  
- Cross-validation: 5-fold
- Confidence Score: 0.97
- Model Agreement: 94%

## Feedback Analysis
Top themes from user feedback:
1. Need for better source quality (addressed)
2. Unclear output structure (addressed)
3. Inconsistent detail level (addressed)
4. Missing citations (addressed)

## Risk Assessment
- Low risk: Changes are additive, preserving existing functionality
- Rollback available if performance degrades
- No tool removals or major structural changes

## Next Steps
1. Monitor performance for 48 hours
2. Collect additional feedback
3. Consider cost optimization if quality targets are met

## Commands
- Apply changes: `crewai apply-improvement 7f3e4a12`
- Rollback: `crewai rollback 7f3e4a12`
- View diff: `crewai diff 7f3e4a12`
- A/B test: `crewai ab-test 7f3e4a12 --traffic=0.1`
```

**7. Rollback Capabilities**

```python
# List all improvements
crewai improvement list

# View specific improvement
crewai improvement show 7f3e4a12

# Rollback to previous version
crewai rollback 7f3e4a12

# Rollback with confirmation
crew.rollback(improvement_id="7f3e4a12", confirm=True)
```

**8. Integration Examples**

### Development Workflow

```python
# Development phase with rapid iteration
dev_crew = Crew(
    agents=[agent1, agent2],
    tasks=[task1, task2],
    retain_improvement_logs=True
)

# Collect feedback over multiple runs
for test_case in test_cases[:20]:
    result = dev_crew.kickoff(inputs=test_case)
    # Auto-prompts for feedback

# Improve based on collected data
dev_crew.improve(
    objective="quality",
    llm="gpt-4-turbo",
    dry_run=True  # Preview changes first
)
```

### Production Monitoring

```python
# Production crew with continuous improvement
prod_crew = Crew(
    agents=[...],
    tasks=[...],
    retain_improvement_logs=True,
    log_retention_days=7  # Keep only recent logs
)

# Weekly improvement cycle
@weekly_schedule
def optimize_crew():
    if prod_crew.get_feedback_count() >= 100:
        prod_crew.improve(
            objective="cost",  # Optimize for cost in production
            constraints={"maintain_quality_score": 4.0},
            require_human_approval=True
        )
```


### Describe alternatives you've considered

1. **Manual Prompt Engineering**: Current approach requiring developers to manually iterate on configurations. This is time-consuming and doesnâ€™t leverage collected data systematically.
1. **Static Optimization**: One-time optimization without continuous improvement. This misses opportunities to adapt to changing requirements and data patterns.
1. **External Services**: Using third-party prompt optimization tools, but these lack deep integration with CrewAIâ€™s agent/task structure and donâ€™t understand the crew dynamics.
1. **Template Library**: Pre-built optimized templates, but these arenâ€™t adaptive to specific use cases and data patterns.
1. **Full Automation**: Fully automated improvements without human control, but this risks unexpected changes and doesnâ€™t align with enterprise governance requirements.
__

### Additional context

### Enterprise Considerations

- **Compliance**: All improvements are logged and auditable
- **Governance**: Human approval workflows for production changes
- **Security**: Improvement data never leaves the local environment
- **Scalability**: Supports managing hundreds of crews across teams

### Performance Optimizations

- Incremental improvement analysis (only process new feedback)
- Caching of improvement suggestions
- Parallel validation of multiple improvement strategies
- Efficient diff generation for large configurations

### Integration Points

- Works with existing CrewAI telemetry
- Compatible with version control systems (Git-friendly YAML diffs)
- Webhook support for CI/CD integration
- API endpoints for programmatic access

### Example Use Cases

**Customer Support Optimization**

```python
support_crew.improve(
    agents=["ticket_analyzer", "response_writer"],
    objective="quality",
    constraints={
        "maintain_response_time": "< 2 minutes",
        "preserve_tone": "friendly and helpful"
    }
)
```

**Content Generation Enhancement**

```python
content_crew.improve(
    tasks=["research_task", "writing_task"],
    objective="quality",
    llm="claude-3-opus",
    test_with_examples=["blog_post", "technical_article", "tutorial"]
)
```

**Cost Reduction for Scale**

```python
analytics_crew.improve(
    objective="cost",
    constraints={
        "maintain_accuracy": 0.95,
        "max_latency_increase": 0.1
    },
    suggest_alternative_llms=True
)
```

### Willingness to Contribute

Yes, I'd be happy to submit a pull request

issues.title: [BUG] Trained data not being used
issues.body: ### Description I have performed some train iteration and found that still when running 'crewai run' trained data not being considered. Doesn't matter which LLM model is being used the result is not being changed according to trained data. Used commands: To train `crewai train -n 2 -f lorem-train.pkl` To run `crewai run`` ### Steps to Reproduce How to reproduce ? 1. in new very new project. (using any llm provider. I tested with llama and gemini) 2. in reporting_task under add "A well-organized written report." as expected_output Now start at least 2 iterations of training and for reporting task give feedback to not include 'conclusion' section and to use numbering for all sections. After training start now normal run with 'crewai run' on same default topic. You will find that now report is being generated as trained during training. (I just provided simple example here, you could play around on feedback). issues.body:
### Description

(This is similar to #2976 but with the crewai tool, not running code).

Simply: trying to run "crewai create crew <project>"

Get: Error fetching provider data: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='raw.githubusercontent.com', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /BerriAI/litellm/main/model_prices_and_context_window.json (Caused by SSLError(SSLEOFError(8, '[SSL: UNEXPECTED_EOF_WHILE_READING] EOF occurred in violation of protocol (_ssl.c:1028)')))

I am running behind Zscaler, so these type of cert issues are never a surprise.  However, I have python working fine.  The latest version of certifi and the REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE env parameter is set.  In a python app, I usually have to set: os.environ['SSL_CERT_FILE'] = certifi.where().  Because this isn't code, I have no place to set that.  

Thoughts on how to work around? Thanks in advance.

crew project creation is successful.

Venv

NONE

### Additional context

N/A

issues.title: [FEATURE]Allow customizing CrewAI code executor to include extra python libraries
issues.body: ### Feature Area Agent capabilities ### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here. Currently, when setting allow_code_execution=True for an agent, CrewAI executes the code inside a sandboxed Docker environment. However, there is no documented way to customize or override the Docker image used for that environment. This creates limitations when trying to execute code that requires additional Python packages (e.g., matplotlib, seaborn, scikit-learn, etc.), which are not pre-installed in the default container. As a result, users either face runtime errors (e.g., ModuleNotFoundError) or have to implement manual workarounds. Right now, users can define a custom tool that mounts and runs Docker manually (e.g., using subprocess with docker run) â€” but this is outside the scope of CrewAIâ€™s built-in execution feature and limits agent autonomy and task simplicity. ### Describe the solution you'd like Introduce a mechanism to specify a custom Docker image when enabling allow_code_execution=True. This could be done via: A new optional argument in the Agent class (e.g., execution_image='my-custom-image') Or via a global environment variable (e.g., CREWAI_CODE_EXEC_IMAGE) CrewAI would then spawn code execution containers using the provided image instead of the default. ### Describe alternatives you've considered _No response_ ### Additional context Benefits Enables agents to run domain-specific or data science code (e.g., charting, ML) without hacky dynamic installs. Provides developers full control over the execution environment. Aligns with secure practices where containers are pre-built and verified for dependencies and safety. Encourages better reproducibility and portability across systems and teams. ### Willingness to Contribute No, I'm just suggesting the idea
issues.author: blazerrt86899

As you can see, this tool already supports that functionality,

issues.title: [FEATURE] @CrewBase can intake agents_config & tasks_config as List
issues.body:
### Feature Area

Core functionality

### Is your feature request related to a an existing bug? Please link it here.

NA

### Describe the solution you'd like

I really enjoy using CrewAI. Iâ€™ve utilized it to build an assistant capable of running multiple flows, each consisting of one or more crews. I appreciate the ability to reuse Agents and Tasks. My goal is to incorporate several agents.yaml and tasks.yaml files, which I can combine within the crew class.

It would be helpful if the `agents_config` and `tasks_config` in the CrewClass could accept a list. For example:
```python
agents_config = ["agents/agents_1.yaml", "agents/agents_2.yaml"]
tasks_config = ["tasks/tasks_1.yaml", "tasks/tasks_2.yaml"]
```

Thank you!

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

Add a loop to the `def load_configurations(self):` in `def CrewBase(cls: T) -> T:` (crew_base.py)  may do the trick.

### Willingness to Contribute

Yes, I'd be happy to submit a pull request

issues.title: [BUG] Crew Agent Experiencing Issues with Basic Task Execution
issues.body:
### Description

Hi team, 
I tried creating a agent that helps in providing the information about employees. When kickoff the crew, agent is invoking all the un necessary tools and going on in a loop for nearly 10 min. Please fins the code files I used:

# crew_agent.py:
from crewai import Agent
from crewai import LLM
import os
from crew_tools import EmployeeSupervisorTool, get_employee_locationTool, get_employee_IDTool, get_employee_skill_setTool

os.environ["AZURE_API_KEY"] = <Azure api key>
os.environ["AZURE_API_BASE"] = <Azure API End Point>
os.environ["AZURE_API_VERSION"] = "2024-10-21"
os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = "dummy"
os.environ["CREWAI_DISABLE_TELEMETRY"] = "true"

gpt_model = LLM(
    model="azure/gpt-4o",
    api_version="2023-05-15"
)


employee_info_agent = Agent(
    role='employee info agent',
    goal="give the exact information about the employee based on the user query",
    verbose=True,
    memoryview=True,
    backstory="""You are an employee information agent. Your task is to provide accurate and relevant information about employees.""",
    tools=[EmployeeSupervisorTool(), get_employee_locationTool(), get_employee_IDTool(), get_employee_skill_setTool()],
    llm=gpt_model,
    allow_delegation= False)

# crew_tools.py:

from crewai.tools import BaseTool
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field
import random
from typing import Type

class emp_name_tools(BaseModel):
    employee_name: str = Field(..., description="The name of the employee.")
class emp_id_tools(BaseModel):
    employee_ID: str = Field(..., description="The ID of the employee.")

class Input(BaseModel):
    user_query: str = Field(..., description="The user query to process.")


class EmployeeSupervisorTool(BaseTool):
    name: str = "get_employee_supervisor"
    description: str = "Returns the supervisor for a given employee ID."
    args_schema: Type[BaseModel]  = emp_id_tools
    
    def _run(self, employee_ID: str) -> str:
        if not employee_ID:
            return "internal processing error :Employee ID is required."
        list_of_supervisors = ['Michael', 'Jessica', 'David', 'Ashley', 'Christopher']
        supervisor = random.choice(list_of_supervisors)
        return f"The supervisor for the given employee is {supervisor}"
    
class get_employee_locationTool(BaseTool):
    name: str = "get_employee_location"
    description: str = "Returns the location of a given employee."
    args_schema: Type[BaseModel] = emp_name_tools

    def _run(self, employee_name: str) -> str:
        if not employee_name:
            return "internal processing error :Employee name is required."
        list_of_locations = ["Hyderbad", "Bangalore", "Chennai", "Mumbai"]
        location = random.choice(list_of_locations)
        return f"The location for {employee_name} is {location}"

class get_employee_IDTool(BaseTool):
    name:str = "get_employee_ID"
    description:str = "Returns the employee ID for a given employee name."
    args_schema: Type[BaseModel] = emp_name_tools

    def _run(self, employee_name: str) -> str:
        if not employee_name:
            return "internal processing error :Employee name is required."
        list_of_ids = ['abd104', '3ni3n', '93jnj', 'ikh2k']
        employee_ID = random.choice(list_of_ids)
        return f"The employee ID for {employee_name} is {employee_ID}"
    

class get_employee_skill_setTool(BaseTool):
    name: str = "get_employee_skill_set"
    description: str = "Returns the skill set of a given employee ID."
    args_schema: Type[BaseModel] = emp_id_tools

    def _run(self, employee_ID: str) -> str:
        if not employee_ID:
            return "internal processing error :Employee ID is required."
        skill = random.choice(["Machine Learning", "Generative AI", "ML Ops", "Image Analysis"])
        return f"The primary skill for the employee with ID {employee_ID} is {skill}"

# crew_tasks.py:
from crewai import Task
from crew_tools import EmployeeSupervisorTool, get_employee_locationTool, get_employee_IDTool, get_employee_skill_setTool



###get employee id task
get_employee_id_task = Task(
    name="get_employee_id",
    description="get the employee ID first of the corresponding employee_name",
    tools=[get_employee_IDTool()],
    async_execution=False,
    expected_output="The employee ID is extracted sucessfully")

###get employee supervisor task
get_employee_supervisor_task = Task(
    name="get_employee_supervisor",
    description= "get the supervisor for the given employee ID",
    tools= [EmployeeSupervisorTool()],
    context=[get_employee_id_task],
    async_execution=False,
    expected_output="The supervisor for the given employee has extracted successfully")


###get employee location task
get_employee_location_task = Task(
    name="get_employee_location",
    description= "get the location of the employee based on the employee name",
    tools=[get_employee_locationTool()],
    context=[get_employee_id_task],
    async_execution=False,
    expected_output="The location for the employee is extracted successfully")

###get employee skill set task
get_employee_skill_set_task = Task(
    name="get_employee_skill_set",
    description= "get the primary skill set of the employee based on the employee ID",
    tools=[get_employee_skill_setTool()],
    context=[get_employee_id_task, get_employee_supervisor_task, get_employee_location_task],
    expected_output="The primary skill associated with the employee has been extracted successfully",
    async_execution=False
)

# crew.py:

from crewai import Crew, Process
from crew_tasks import get_employee_id_task, get_employee_supervisor_task, get_employee_location_task, get_employee_skill_set_task
from crew_agent import employee_info_agent
import os
from crewai import LLM


os.environ["AZURE_API_KEY"] = <azure api key>
os.environ["AZURE_API_BASE"] = <azure end point>
os.environ["AZURE_API_VERSION"] = "2024-10-21"

os.environ["CREWAI_DISABLE_TELEMETRY"] = "true"
###llm

gpt_model = LLM(
    model="azure/gpt-4o",
    api_version="2023-05-15"
)

crew = Crew(
    agents=[employee_info_agent],
    tasks= [get_employee_id_task, get_employee_supervisor_task, get_employee_location_task, get_employee_skill_set_task],
    verbose=True,
    process= Process.hierarchical,

    max_rpm = 100,

result = crew.kickoff(inputs={'user_input': 'What is the location of the employee named Jhon?'})
print(result)

### Steps to Reproduce

### Expected behavior

when user asks something like "I would like to know the skill set of Jhon" it should be triggering only relevant tools that are need to get the skill set and have to return response that contains jhon skill set. issues.title: [BUG] LLMStreamChunkEvent Events Emitted Out of Chronological Order
issues.body:
### Description

**Description:**
LLMStreamChunkEvent events are being emitted out of chronological order during streaming LLM responses. Events created earlier (with earlier timestamps) are being emitted after events created later, causing confusion for event handlers that expect sequential chunk processing.




### Steps to Reproduce

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Create an LLM instance with streaming enabled: `LLM(model="gpt-4o", stream=True)`
2. Set up an event listener for `LLMStreamChunkEvent` that logs timestamps
3. Make an LLM call that generates multiple chunks: `llm.call("Tell me a story")`
4. Observe the event timestamps vs emission order


### Expected behavior

Events received on webhooks should not be Out Of Order 

### Screenshots/Code snippets

**Expected Behavior:**
Events should be emitted in chronological order matching their timestamp sequence. If chunk " How" is created at `17:10:38.834956` and chunk " can" is created at `17:10:38.835633`, then " How" should be emitted before " can".

**Code Snippets:**
```json
"llm_stream_chunk": [
    {
        "timestamp": "2025-06-13T17:10:38.835633",
        "chunk": " can"
    },
    {
        "timestamp": "2025-06-13T17:10:38.834956", 
        "chunk": " How"  // Earlier timestamp but emitted later!
    }
]
```

**Evidence:**
Real event data showing timestamps out of order:
- `17:10:38.835633` - " can" 
- `17:10:38.834956` - " How" *(677Âµs earlier but emitted after)*
- `17:10:38.904691` - " today"  
- `17:10:38.903933` - " you" *(758Âµs earlier but emitted after)*

**Root Cause:**
1. `BaseEvent` sets timestamp during creation: `timestamp: datetime = Field(default_factory=datetime.now)`
2. Complex chunk extraction logic in `_handle_streaming_response()` (lines 520-530) causes variable processing delays
3. Events created with timestamp T1, T2 get emitted in reverse order due to processing time differences


**Additional Context:**
This affects any application relying on event stream order for real-time processing, chat interfaces, or debugging. The issue is subtle but breaks the assumption that streaming events arrive in temporal sequence.

### Operating System

Ubuntu 20.04

### Python Version

3.10

### crewAI Version

0.126.0

### crewAI Tools Version

N/A

### Virtual Environment

Venv

### Evidence

Evidence:
Real event data showing timestamps out of order:

17:10:38.835633 - " can"
17:10:38.834956 - " How" (677Âµs earlier but emitted after)
17:10:38.904691 - " today"
17:10:38.903933 - " you" (758Âµs earlier but emitted after)


```json
{
   "llm_stream_chunk":[
      {
         "timestamp":"2025-06-13T17:10:38.813775",
         "id":"140676629109312",
         "execution_id":"517f72a8-fab2-4a26-a017-dd76a4ce9c28",
         "type":"llm_stream_chunk",
         "data":{
            "source_fingerprint":null,
            "source_type":null,
            "fingerprint_metadata":null,
            "chunk":"!",
            "tool_call":null
         }
      },
      {
         "timestamp":"2025-06-13T17:10:38.835633",
         "id":"140676829795248",
         "execution_id":"517f72a8-fab2-4a26-a017-dd76a4ce9c28",
         "type":"llm_stream_chunk",
         "data":{
            "source_fingerprint":null,
            "source_type":null,
            "fingerprint_metadata":null,
            "chunk":" can",
            "tool_call":null
         }
      },
      {
         "timestamp":"2025-06-13T17:10:38.834956",
         "id":"140676629117472",
         "execution_id":"517f72a8-fab2-4a26-a017-dd76a4ce9c28",
         "type":"llm_stream_chunk",
         "data":{
            "source_fingerprint":null,
            "source_type":null,
            "fingerprint_metadata":null,
            "chunk":" How",
            "tool_call":null
         }
      },
      {
         "timestamp":"2025-06-13T17:10:38.858106",
         "id":"140676629117472",

         "type":"llm_stream_chunk",

            "fingerprint_metadata":null,
            "chunk":" I",
            "tool_call":null
         }
      },
      {
         "timestamp":"2025-06-13T17:10:38.904691",
         "id":"140676629422768",
         "execution_id":"517f72a8-fab2-4a26-a017-dd76a4ce9c28",
         "type":"llm_stream_chunk",
         "data":{
            "source_fingerprint":null,
            "source_type":null,
            "fingerprint_metadata":null,
            "chunk":" today",
            "tool_call":null
         }
      },
      {
         "timestamp":"2025-06-13T17:10:38.903933",
         "id":"140676629421968",
         "execution_id":"517f72a8-fab2-4a26-a017-dd76a4ce9c28",
         "type":"llm_stream_chunk",
         "data":{
            "source_fingerprint":null,
            "source_type":null,
            "fingerprint_metadata":null,
            "chunk":" you",
            "tool_call":null
         }
      },
      {
         "timestamp":"2025-06-13T17:10:38.911254",
         "id":"140676629421968",
         "execution_id":"517f72a8-fab2-4a26-a017-dd76a4ce9c28",
         "type":"llm_stream_chunk",
         "data":{
            "source_fingerprint":null,
            "source_type":null,
            "fingerprint_metadata":null,
            "chunk":"?",
            "tool_call":null
         }
      }
   ]
}
```

### Possible Solution

**Possible Solution:**
1. **Move timestamp to emission time:** Set timestamp when `crewai_event_bus.emit()` is called, not during event creation
2. **Add sequence numbers:** Include a monotonic sequence counter to maintain order regardless of processing delays
3. **Batch events per iteration:** Collect all events for each chunk iteration, then emit in creation order


### Additional context

N/A
